citations.narrative:
Multiple outdoor enclosure runs have rust and holes in the metal surface of the kennel building. Many of these holes have
sharp points and jagged edges which are a risk of injury to the enclosed animals. These damaged areas are also potential
access points for rodents and pests. The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of
materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Licensee must
repair these enclosures and must maintain facilities in good repair.
To be corrected by April 30, 2025

There are several areas of standing water around the facility. One corner has a large pool of water with algae growth and
debris. A drainage ditch has pooled water containing debris and waste. Accumulation of waste and water is a potential
attractant for pests and insects which could have a negative impact on the dogs. Housing facilities must be equipped with
disposal facilities and drainage systems that are constructed and operated so that animal waste and water are rapidly
eliminated. Disposal and drainage systems must minimize vermin and pest infestation, insects, odors, and disease
hazards. The facility must ensure that the drainage system is functioning properly and must address the areas of standing
water surrounding the kennel building.
To be corrected by April 30, 2025

The licensee could not present an exercise program approved by the attending veterinarian. Dealers, exhibitors, and
research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for
exercise. The plan must include written standard procedures to be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise. The
plan must be made available to APHIS upon request.
To be corrected by April 14, 2025.

citations.desc: Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control.
citations.narrative:
The area around the kennel building is overgrown with tall grass and weeds. Overgrown vegetation is potential harborage
for pests and insects and could be contributing to the facility pest control problem. Weeds and grass near the kennel
building should be properly controlled to help protect the animals from exposure to pests.
Premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings and surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in
good repair to protect the animals from injury, to facilitate the husbandry practices required in this subpart, and to reduce
or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents and other pests and vermin. Weeds, grasses, and bushes must be
controlled so as to facilitate cleaning of the premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of the
animals.
To be corrected by April 14, 2025.
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 3/31/2025 and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on
3/31/2025.
This inspection was conducted with the Licensee on 3/31/2025. The exit interview was conducted with the Licensee on
3/31/2025.
Additional Inspectors:
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.1(a) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
Multiple outdoor enclosure runs have rust and holes in the metal surface of the kennel building. Many of these holes have 
sharp points and jagged edges which are a risk of injury to the enclosed animals. These damaged areas are also potential 
access points for rodents and pests. The surfaces of housing facilities must be constructed in a manner and made of 
materials that allow them to be readily cleaned and sanitized or removed or replaced when worn or soiled. Licensee must 
repair these enclosures and must maintain facilities in good repair. 
 
To be corrected by April 30, 2025 
3.1(f) 
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There are several areas of standing water around the facility. One corner has a large pool of water with algae growth and 
debris. A drainage ditch has pooled water containing debris and waste. Accumulation of waste and water is a potential 
attractant for pests and insects which could have a negative impact on the dogs. Housing facilities must be equipped with 
disposal facilities and drainage systems that are constructed and operated so that animal waste and water are rapidly 
eliminated. Disposal and drainage systems must minimize vermin and pest infestation, insects, odors, and disease 
hazards. The facility must ensure that the drainage system is functioning properly and must address the areas of standing 
water surrounding the kennel building. 
 
To be corrected by April 30, 2025 
3.8 
   
Exercise for dogs. 
The licensee could not present an exercise program approved by the attending veterinarian. Dealers, exhibitors, and 
research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide dogs with the opportunity for 
exercise. The plan must include written standard procedures to be followed in providing the opportunity for exercise. The 
plan must be made available to APHIS upon request.

To be corrected by April 14, 2025. 
3.11(c) 
   
Cleaning, sanitization, housekeeping, and pest control. 
The area around the kennel building is overgrown with tall grass and weeds. Overgrown vegetation is potential harborage 
for pests and insects and could be contributing to the facility pest control problem. Weeds and grass near the kennel 
building should be properly controlled to help protect the animals from exposure to pests. 
Premises where housing facilities are located, including buildings and surrounding grounds, must be kept clean and in 
good repair to protect the animals from injury, to facilitate the husbandry practices required in this subpart, and to reduce 
or eliminate breeding and living areas for rodents and other pests and vermin. Weeds, grasses, and bushes must be 
controlled so as to facilitate cleaning of the premises and pest control, and to protect the health and well-being of the 
animals.  
 
To be corrected by April 14, 2025. 
 
This is a continuation of the report for the routine inspection conducted 3/31/2025 and contains the remaining non-
compliances found during the inspection. The exit briefing for the items included on this report was conducted on 
3/31/2025. 
 
This inspection was conducted with the Licensee on 3/31/2025. The exit interview was conducted with the Licensee on 
3/31/2025. 
 
Additional Inspectors: 
MICHAEL TYGART, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n
